Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to step into the emergency room. It was my husband, his voice trembling, barely holding back tears. He needed me—he was unraveling, the weight of his crisis pressing down, and I was his anchor. He pleaded for me to come home, to just sit with him, to listen. But as I hung up, a nurse rushed over, urgency in her eyes. A patient had just arrived, feverish and delirious, the infection spreading so quickly that every second counted. I was the only doctor on shift who could prescribe the right treatment. My mind raced. My husband needed my presence, my comfort, my undivided attention. My patient needed my expertise, my swift action, my focus. I felt torn in two, the expectations of wife and doctor pulling me in opposite directions, each demand as urgent and vital as the other. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, caught between the person I loved and the oath I had taken.
